rounds.observation:
You are Player 0 in the Negotiation Game.
You have some resources, and your task is to trade such that the total value of your resources increases.
The resources and associated values you currently have are:
	+ [Wheat]   Qty: 21   Value: 6
	+ [Wood]    Qty: 10   Value: 11
	+ [Sheep]   Qty: 17   Value: 18
	+ [Brick]   Qty: 9    Value: 30
	+ [Ore]     Qty: 18   Value: 40
At each turn, you can talk to your opponent and make a trade offer.
Use the following special tokens for actions:
  - '[Offer: 3 Sheep, 2 Ore -> 5 Brick, 2 Sheep]': [Offer: Offered Resources -> Requested Resources]
  - '[Accept]': To accept an incoming offer.
  - '[Deny]': To deny an incoming offer (default).
The game lasts for 10 turns in total.
rounds.response:
Turn 1  
My total value: 21·6 + 10·11 + 17·18 + 9·30 + 18·40 = 1 658

Right now my worst value-per-unit resource is Wheat (6 apiece).  
Brick is over-valued (30 apiece) but I only have 9; getting more would immediately add value.  
Sheep are close to Brick in value on my sheet (18 vs 30) – I’m willing to shed some to get Brick.

So a small opening offer:  
“Let’s see if you value Brick a bit lower than I do – would you take 3 of my Sheep for 2 Brick?”  
[Offer: 3 Sheep -> 2 Brick]

rounds.response:
Current Turn: 2/10  
My goal is to increase total value, so every proposed trade must bring me strictly more future value than the future value of the resources I give away.

Step 1 – Check value gain for sheep → brick
I lose 3×18 = 54 value now, but gain 2×30 = 60 value now, for a net +6. That is always worth it.

Next-best target is wood (value 11), but brick is worth far more. Therefore I’ll stick to the idea of acquiring extra brick at the same exchange rate (≈1.5 sheep per brick).

Step 2 – Try a larger bundle (larger bundle is more efficient in single turn)
I offer to give up 6 sheep and obtain 4 brick:

[Offer: 6 Sheep -> 4 Brick]

rounds.response:
After weighing this against your last two moves (and what you know about hold-outs from earlier logs), Player 1 is clearly anchoring on a 1.5 Sheep : 1 Brick valuation (their counter-offer 2B → 3S).  
My internal valuation is 30 : 18 (≈1.67), so that 1.5 line arguably isn’t awful, but simply accepting it gives me zero & gains them immediate value. I can do better elsewhere or squeeze more items so my marginal value per Brick is ≥30.

Immediate response:
[Deny]

…while signalling willingness to negotiate if they give slightly more Brick per Sheep.

Next, I’ll probe for a blended deal that lets me unload Wheat (my lowest value item at 6) in exchange for Brick, something like:

[Offer: 5 Wheat -> 3 Brick]

rounds.response:
My opponent wants 6 Wheat for 3 Brick.  
Let’s do the numbers:

‐ 6 Wheat value = 6 × 6 = 36  
‐ 3 Brick value  = 3 × 30 = 90  

Net gain for me: 90 – 36 = +54 value; positive for me, so I accept.

[Accept]

rounds.response:
Let me analyse the situation carefully.

Current board state (after the last acceptance):

Resources after Trade #1 (6 Wheat → 3 Brick)
- Wheat: 21 – 6 = 15 (value 6)  
- Wood: 10 (11)  
- Sheep: 17 (18)  
- Brick: 9 + 3 = 12 (30)  
- Ore: 18 (40)

Incoming offer from Player 1:  
[3 Ore → 2 Brick]

Value check  
3 Ore = 3 × 40 = 120 points  
2 Brick = 2 × 30 = 60 points

Giving up Ore (our highest-value commodity) for only 2 Brick loses 60 total value, so I should decline.

[Deny]

rounds.response:
Player 0's turn 9  
Current portfolio valuations (after the Brick-for-Wheat swap):
• Wheat 26 → 156  
• Wood 10 → 110  
• Sheep 17 → 306  
• Brick 12 → 360  
• Ore 18 → 720  
Total value = 1 652

Goal: still push marginal value of Brick higher and reduce any excess Wheat/Sheep.

I believe a 3-for-2 ratio on Brick is the market-tested line (it was just refused both ways at that exact ratio: me 3 Sheep → 2 Brick, and them 2 Brick → 3 Sheep).  
But they value Brick very highly, so to push the deal through I’ll let them buy Brick in smaller chunks with a slight premium.

[Offer: 1 Brick -> 2 Sheep, 1 Wheat]
